arm_group.description: Patients are grouped into 2: Good and poor collateral development
Patients are grouped into 2: Good and poor collateral development

brief_summary.textblock:
Monocyte heterogeneity in peripheral blood seems to be important in coronary collateral
      development in non-diabetic patients with stable coronary artery disease. Our aim in this
      study is to find out any possible relationship between the levels of circulating monocyte
      subsets and coronary collateral development in type 2 diabetic patients.

clinical_study.brief_title: The Association Between Monocyte Subsets and Coronary Collateral Development in Diabetes Mellitus

detailed_description.textblock:
83 diabetic patients with severe coronary artery disease were enrolled in the study. These
      patients were investigated according to their collateral development. Monocytes and their
      subtypes, namely CD14++CD16- and CD14+CD16+ cells were compared in 2 groups

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  presence of > 95% stenosis of at least one major coronary artery in their first
             coronary angiogram.

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Patients experiencing acute coronary syndrome either with or without ST elevation in
             the last one month

          -  Evidence of ongoing infection and inflammation, known malignancy and chronic kidney
             disease

study_pop.textblock:
The study population consisted of 83 consecutive type 2 diabetic patients who have
        undergone coronary angiography because of stable symptoms and signs of coronary artery
        disease.  The main inclusion criterion was the presence of >95% stenosis of at least one
        major coronary artery in their first coronary angiogram.

clinical_study.official_title: The Association Between Monocyte Subsets and Coronary Collateral Development in Diabetes Mellitus

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.study_design: Observational Model: Case Control, Time Perspective: Cross-Sectional
